questions.question_text:
As a cloud-native developer, you have written a web service for your company. You have used Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) API Gateway service to expose the HTTP backend. However, your security team has suggested that your web service should handle Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attack. You are time- constrained and you need to make sure that this is implemented as soon as possible.
What should you do in this scenario? (Choose the best answer.)

choices.A: Use OCI virtual cloud network (VCN) segregation to control DDoS.
choices.B: Use a third party service integration to implement a DDoS attack mitigation.
choices.D: Re-write your web service and implement rate limiting.
choices.C: Use OCI API Gateway service and configure rate limiting.

discussion.content:
D, is the correct answer.
Using WAF

questions.question_text:
A leading insurance firm is hosting its customer portal in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Container Engine for Kubernetes with an OCI Autonomous Database.
Their support team discovered a lot of SQL injection attempts and cross-site scripting attacks to the portal, which is starting to affect the production environment.
What should they implement to mitigate this attack? (Choose the best answer.)

comments.content: Agree, I don't think we can do this - "Add the on-premises Linux server in the dynamic group."
You can't add onprem servers in the OCI policy IAM.

discussion.content:
I would go for C.
Dynamic Groups are for instances and not for iam user
The correct answer is C. The keyword here is "the secure way" and the "access OCI services using SDK."
Agree with C. Only resources in OCI can be added to policies or dynamic groups, no On prem resources. Key-pair is the possible way of authorization of users in OCI from SDK.

choices.D: Create a new OCI IAM user, add the user to a group associated with a policy that grants the desired permissions to OCI services. In the on-premises Linux server, add the user name and password to a file used by Node.js authentication.
choices.A: Create a new OCI IAM user associated with a dynamic group and a policy that grants the desired permissions to OCI services. Add the on-premises Linux server in the dynamic group.
choices.C: Create a new OCI IAM user, add the user to a group associated with a policy that grants the desired permissions to OCI services. In the on-premises Linux server, generate the keypair used for signing API requests and upload the public key to the IAM user.
choices.B: Create an OCI IAM policy with the appropriate permissions to access the required OCI services and assign the policy to the on-premises Linux server.

questions.question_text:
A programmer is developing a Node.js application which will run in a Linux server on their on-premises data center. This application will access various Oracle
Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) services using OCI SDKs.
What is the secure way to access OCI services with OCI Identity and Access Management (IAM)? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
The answer is definitely C (content-type).

For GET and DELETE requests (when there's no content in the request body), the signing string must include at least these headers:

(request-target) (as described in draft-cavage-http-signatures-08)
host
date or x-date (if both are included, Oracle uses x-date)

https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/signingrequests.htm

Selected Answer: C
For GET and DELETE requests (when there's no content in the request body), the signing string must include at least these headers:
* (request-target) (as described in draft-cavage-http-signatures-08)
* host
* date or x-date (if both are included, Oracle uses x-date)

Reference: https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/signingrequests.htm#five
